examples.text: All horses are animals, but not all animals are horses.
Cars were coming from all directions *(= every direction)*.
All the people you invited are coming.
All my plants have died.
All five of them are hard workers.
All wood tends to shrink.
You've had all the fun and I've had all the hard work.
All this mail must be answered.
He has lost all his money.

definitions.definition: used with singular nouns showing something has been happening for a whole period of time

examples.text: They have worked hard all year.
She was unemployed for all that time.
In all honesty *(= being as honest as I can)*, I can't agree.

definitions.definition: consisting or appearing to consist of one thing only

examples.text: The magazine was all advertisements.
She was **all smiles** *(= smiling a lot)*.
He denied all knowledge of the crime.
I'm bored by history—dates and battles and all that stuff.
For all its clarity of style, the book is not easy reading.

definitions.definition: used to say that something is not important or of no interest or value to you/somebody

examples.text: **For all I know** she's still living in Boston.
You can do what you like, for all I care.
For all the good it's done we might as well not have bothered.
He doesn't sing all that well.

definitions.definition: not as much as has been suggested

examples.text: They're not as rich as all that.
We didn't play particularly well, but we didn't do as badly as all that.
I've locked myself out. Of all the stupid things to do!

definitions.definition: used to express surprise because somebody/something seems the least likely person, example, etc.

examples.text: I didn't think you, of all people, would become a vegetarian.

definitions.definition: in or from all directions; everywhere

examples.text: We realized we were surrounded on all sides.
Disaster threatens on every side.
She was bombarded with questions from all sides.

wordOrigin: Old English all, eall, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch al and German all.
